ai-mn15:1.2_0: At one time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was staying in the land of the Bhaggas on Crocodile Hill, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.
ai-mn15:1.3_0: There Venerable Mahāmoggallāna addressed the mendicants:
ai-mn15:2.1_0: “Reverends, if a mendicant stays at ease,
ai-mn15:2.2_0: other mendicants to admonish them. But they’re hard to admonish, having qualities that make them hard to admonish. They're impatient, and don't take instruction respectfully. So their spiritual companions don’t think it’s worth advising and instructing them, and that person doesn’t gain their trust.
ai-mn15:3.1_0: And what are the qualities that make them hard to admonish?
ai-mn15:3.2_0: Firstly, a mendicant has wicked desires, having fallen under the sway of wicked desires.
ai-mn15:3.4_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.5_0: Furthermore, a mendicant glorifies themselves and puts others down. ...
ai-mn15:3.6_0: Any mendicant who glorifies themselves and puts others down.
ai-mn15:3.7_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.8_0: They’re irritable, and stubborn due to anger ...
ai-mn15:3.9_0: Take a mendicant who is irritable and hostile.
ai-mn15:3.10_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.11_0: They’re irritable, and hostile due to anger ...
ai-mn15:3.12_0: Take a mendicant who is irritable, and hostile due to anger.
ai-mn15:3.13_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.14_0: They’re irritable, and stubborn due to anger ...
ai-mn15:3.15_0: “It’s when a mendicant is irritable, and stubborn due to anger.
ai-mn15:3.16_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.17_0: They’re irritable, and blurt out words bordering on anger ...
ai-mn15:3.18_0: The anger irritable, and blurt out words:
ai-mn15:3.19_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.20_0: When accused, they retort to the accuser ...
ai-mn15:3.21_0: When accused, they retort to the accuser ...
ai-mn15:3.22_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.23_0: When accused, they rebuke the accuser ...
ai-mn15:3.24_0: When accused, they rebuke the accuser ...
ai-mn15:3.25_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.26_0: When accused, they retort to the accuser ...
ai-mn15:3.27_0: When accused, they retort to the accuser ...
ai-mn15:3.28_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.29_0: When accused, they dodge the issue, distract the discussion with irrelevant points, and display annoyance, hate, and bitterness ...
ai-mn15:3.30_0: When accused, they dodge the issue, distract the discussion with irrelevant points, and display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
ai-mn15:3.31_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.32_0: When accused, they don’t accept the consequences of their deeds ...
ai-mn15:3.33_0: When accused, they don’t accept the consequences of their deeds:
ai-mn15:3.34_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.35_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is offensive and contemptuous ...
ai-mn15:3.36_0: Any mendicant who is offensive and contemptuous—
ai-mn15:3.37_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.39_0: That mendicant is jealous and stingy ...
ai-mn15:3.40_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.42_0: Whatever a mendicant is devious and deceitful—
ai-mn15:3.43_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.45_0: Whatever a mendicant is obstinate and vain ...
ai-mn15:3.46_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.47_0: Furthermore, a mendicant is attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.
ai-mn15:3.48_0: Any of these is attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.
ai-mn15:3.49_0: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:3.50_0: These are the qualities that make them hard to admonish.
ai-mn15:4.2_0: other mendicants to admonish them. But they’re easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They're impatient, and don't take instruction respectfully. So their spiritual companions think it’s worth advising and instructing them, and that person should gain their trust.
ai-mn15:5.1_0: And what are the qualities that make them easy to admonish?
ai-mn15:5.2_0: Firstly, a mendicant has no wicked desires, having fallen under the sway of wicked desires.
ai-mn15:5.3_0: ‘Whatever monk has wicked desires, he doesn’t have wicked desires, falling under the sway of wicked desires.
ai-mn15:5.4_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.5_0: Furthermore, a mendicant glorifies themselves and puts others down.
ai-mn15:5.6_0: Any mendicant who doesn’t glorify themselves and put others down.
ai-mn15:5.7_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.8_0: They’re not irritable, and stubborn due to anger ...
ai-mn15:5.9_0: Take a mendicant who is not irritable and hostile.
ai-mn15:5.10_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.11_0: They’re not irritable, and hostile due to anger ...
ai-mn15:5.13_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.14_0: They’re not irritable, and stubborn due to anger ...
ai-mn15:5.16_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.17_0: They’re not irritable, and blurt out words bordering on anger ...
ai-mn15:5.18_0: They’re not irritable, and blurt out words:
ai-mn15:5.19_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.20_0: When accused, they don’t smear the accuser ...
ai-mn15:5.21_0: When accused, they don’t remind the accuser, saying,
ai-mn15:5.22_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.23_0: When accused, they don’t rebuke the accuser ...
ai-mn15:5.24_0: When accused, they don’t rebuke the accuser ...
ai-mn15:5.25_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.26_0: When accused, they don’t retort to the accuser ...
ai-mn15:5.27_0: When accused, they don’t retort to the accuser, saying,
ai-mn15:5.28_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.29_0: When accused, they don’t dodge the issue ...
ai-mn15:5.30_0: When accused, they don’t dodge the issue, distract the discussion with irrelevant points, and display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
ai-mn15:5.31_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.32_0: When accused, they accept the consequences of their deeds ...
ai-mn15:5.33_0: When accused, they accept the consequences of their deeds:
ai-mn15:5.34_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.37_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.38_0: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t jealous and stingy ...
ai-mn15:5.39_0: Any mendicant who isn’t jealous of stinginess—
ai-mn15:5.40_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.42_0: Any mendicant who is not devious or deceitful
ai-mn15:5.43_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.45_0: When a mendicant hasn’t been obstinate and vain
ai-mn15:5.46_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.47_0: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t attached to their own views, not holding them tight, but letting them go easily.
ai-mn15:5.48_0: Any mendicant who isn’t attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.
ai-mn15:5.49_0: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
ai-mn15:5.50_0: These are the qualities that make them easy to admonish.
ai-mn15:6.1_0: In such a case, a mendicant should measure themselves against another like this.
ai-mn15:6.2_0: ‘This person has wicked desires, having fallen under the sway of wicked desires. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
ai-mn15:6.3_0: And if I were to fall under the sway of wicked desires, others wouldn’t like or approve of me.’
ai-mn15:6.4_0: A mendicant who knows this should think: ‘I will not have wicked desires, falling under the sway of wicked desires.’
ai-mn15:6.5_0: ‘This person who glorifies themselves and puts others down. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
ai-mn15:6.6_0: And if I were to glorify myself and put others down others on account of my own.’
ai-mn15:6.7_0: A mendicant who knows this should give rise to the thought: ‘I will not be glorious.’
ai-mn15:6.8_0: ‘This person is irritable and hostile. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
ai-mn15:6.9_0: And if I’m irritable, and lack of anger, others wouldn’t like or approve of me.’
ai-mn15:6.10_0: A mendicant who knows this should not give rise to anger, but will not be irritable.
ai-mn15:6.11_0: ‘This person is irritable and hostile. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
ai-mn15:6.12_0: And if I’m irritable, and hostile due to anger, they don’t like it either.’
ai-mn15:6.13_0: A mendicant who knows this should not give rise to anger, nor will I irritable by anger.
ai-mn15:6.14_0: ‘This person is irritable and hostile. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
ai-mn15:6.15_0: And if I were to ask someone else, they wouldn’t like that and disliked by others.’
ai-mn15:6.16_0: A mendicant who knows this should not give rise to anger, nor will I subsistantively grasp the mind.
ai-mn15:6.17_0: ‘This person is irritable and hostile. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
ai-mn15:6.18_0: And if I were to anger, others wouldn’t like that either.’
ai-mn15:6.19_0: When a mendicant knows that they don’t give rise to anger, they should think: ‘I will not be irritable.’
ai-mn15:6.20_0: ‘This person accuses a person who retorts to the accuser ...
ai-mn15:6.21_0: But if I accused someone else, they wouldn’t like that either.’
ai-mn15:6.22_0: A mendicant who doesn’t understand this should try to accuse another like this: ‘I’ll scatter the mind.’
ai-mn15:6.23_0: ‘This person accuses themselves with their accusation. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
ai-mn15:6.24_0: And if I accused him, they dislike him.’
ai-mn15:6.25_0: When a mendicant knows that they’re accused like this, they shouldn’t give rise to confidence in those without it.
ai-mn15:6.26_0: ‘This person accuses someone who retorts to the accuser ...
ai-mn15:6.27_0: But if I was accused by the accuser, others wouldn’t like or approve of me.’
ai-mn15:6.28_0: A mendicant who doesn’t understand this should make an effort to get him reply. They don’t think: ‘I’ll neither confesse their mind.’
ai-mn15:6.30_0: But if I accused someone else dodge the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points, and displayed annoyance, hate, and bitterness.’
ai-mn15:6.31_0: When a mendicant is accused like this, they shouldn’t dodge the issue, distract the discussion with irrelevant points. They won’t display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
ai-mn15:6.32_0: ‘This person doesn’t expose their accusation to you. And I don’t like or approve of a person.
ai-mn15:6.33_0: But I won’t accuse others of convicing me, wouldn’t like or approve of others.’
ai-mn15:6.34_0: A mendicant who knows this should give rise to the thought: ‘I will understand this.’
ai-mn15:6.35_0: ‘This person is disliked by me. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
ai-mn15:6.36_0: And if I were to dislike this others, others wouldn’t like or approve of me.’
ai-mn15:6.37_0: A mendicant who knows this should think: ‘I will not be without getting rid of greed.’
ai-mn15:6.38_0: ‘This person is jealous of jealousy and unloved. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
ai-mn15:6.39_0: And if I were to be jealous, others wouldn’t like or approve of me.’
ai-mn15:6.40_0: A mendicant who knows this should give rise to the thought: ‘I will not be jealousy.’
ai-mn15:6.41_0: ‘This person is disliked by Māra. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
ai-mn15:6.42_0: But if I were to dislike someone else’s devious or deceitful, others wouldn’t like or approve of me.’
ai-mn15:6.43_0: A mendicant who knows this should think: ‘I will not be devious or deceitful.’
ai-mn15:6.44_0: ‘This person is irred by a person, unpleasant to me. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
ai-mn15:6.45_0: And if I were to dislike this, others wouldn’t like or approve of me.’
ai-mn15:6.46_0: A mendicant who knows this should give rise to the thought: ‘I will not be attached to my own mind.’
ai-mn15:6.47_0: ‘This person is attached to their own views, holding them tight and refusing to let go. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
ai-mn15:6.48_0: And if I were to be attached to my own views, holding them tight and refusing to let go, others wouldn’t like or approve of me.’
ai-mn15:6.49_0: A mendicant who knows this should give rise to the thought: ‘I will not be attached to my own views, holding them tight, but will let them go easily.’
ai-mn15:7.1_0: In such a case, a mendicant should check themselves like this:
ai-mn15:7.2_0: ‘Do I have wicked desires? Have I fallen under the sway of wicked desires?’
ai-mn15:7.3_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-mn15:7.5_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-mn15:7.6_0: they haven’t fallen under the sway of wicked desires. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
ai-mn15:7.7_0: Furthermore, a mendicant should check themselves like this:
ai-mn15:7.9_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-mn15:7.10_0: they haven’t achieved mastery. They should make an effort to give up those bad, unskillful qualities.
ai-mn15:7.11_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that

ai-mn15:7.18_0: they’re not irritable, and full of rapture. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
ai-mn15:7.19_0: Furthermore, a mendicant should check themselves like this:
ai-mn15:7.21_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that this is irritable and hostile. Then they should make an effort to give up those bad, unskillful qualities.
ai-mn15:7.22_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that this is irritable, hostility, disdain, and full of rapture. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
ai-mn15:7.23_0: Furthermore, a mendicant should check themselves like this:

ai-mn15:7.27_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-mn15:7.28_0: they are not angry and upset with anger. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
ai-mn15:7.29_0: Furthermore, a mendicant should check themselves like this:
ai-mn15:7.30_0: ‘When what anger is there anger, enmity and ill will?’
ai-mn15:7.31_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-mn15:7.32_0: they are irritable, and blurt out words. Then they should make an effort to give up those bad, unskillful qualities.
ai-mn15:7.33_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-mn15:7.34_0: they’re not irritable, and hostile. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
ai-mn15:7.35_0: Furthermore, a mendicant should check themselves like this:
ai-mn15:7.36_0: ‘When someone accuses me and replys back to the beginning, “I’m getting someone else.”’
ai-mn15:7.37_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that they have been accused like this: ‘I’m refuted.’ Then they should make an effort to give up those bad, unskillful qualities.
ai-mn15:7.38_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-mn15:7.39_0: they’re accused, but don’t respond your words. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
ai-mn15:7.40_0: Furthermore, a mendicant should check themselves like this:
ai-mn15:7.41_0: ‘When someone accuses me and rebukes me to rebuke me?’
ai-mn15:7.42_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that ‘I’m accused’. They should make an effort to give up those bad, unskillful qualities.
ai-mn15:7.43_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-mn15:7.44_0: they’re accused, and don’t rebuke them with rapture and joy, they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
ai-mn15:7.45_0: Furthermore, a mendicant should check themselves like this:
ai-mn15:7.46_0: ‘When someone accuses me and retorts to the one who accuses me?’
ai-mn15:7.47_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-mn15:7.48_0: they’re accused with the accused, they should make an effort to give up those bad, unskillful qualities.
ai-mn15:7.49_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-mn15:7.50_0: they’re accused, but don’t retort to. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.

ai-mn15:7.52_0: ‘When accused, do I dodge the issue, distract the discussion with irrelevant points, and display annoyance, hate, and bitterness?’

ai-mn15:7.88_0: ‘Why is it attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go?’
ai-mn15:7.89_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
ai-mn15:7.90_0: they are attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go. Then they should make an effort to give up those bad, unskillful qualities.

ai-mn15:7.92_0: they’re not attached to their own views, holding them tight, but let them go easily. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
ai-mn15:8.1_0: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant sees that they haven’t given up all these bad, unskillful qualities. Then they should make an effort to give them all up.
ai-mn15:8.2_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant sees that they have given up all these bad, unskillful qualities. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
ai-mn15:8.3_0: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they see any dirt or blemish there, they’d try to remove it.
ai-mn15:8.4_0: If he sees that it is not, then it is pleased.
ai-mn15:8.6_0: In the same way, suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant sees that they haven’t given up all these bad, unskillful qualities. Then they should make an effort to give them all up.
ai-mn15:8.7_0: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant sees that they have given up all these bad, unskillful qualities. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.”
ai-mn15:8.8_0: That is what Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said,
ai-mn15:8.9_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what Mahāmoggallāna said.
ai-mn15:8.10_0: The fifth section on the supreme chapter on expressions is finished.
